defs.etymology: From Sanskrit भवति (bhavati, “be”) via Prakrit.

text: third-person singular present indicative of होना (honā): (he, she, it) is

examples: तपाईको नाम के हो ?tapāīko nām ke ho ?What is your name?
tapāīko nām ke ho ?
What is your name?

defs.etymology: Inherited from Old Hindi मैं (maiṃ), from Sauraseni Apabhramsa मइं (maĩ), from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀫𑀏 (mae), from Sanskrit मया (mayā), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *máyaH (the instrumental singular of *aȷ́ʰám (“I”)), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁móy.Cognate to Punjabi ਮੈਂ (maĩ), Nepali म (ma), Assamese মই (moi), Oriya ମୁଁ (mum̐) , Sylheti ꠝꠥꠁ (mui), Kamta মুই (mui), Marathi मी (mī), all deriving from oblique forms of the first-person personal pronoun.

text: मैं • (ma͠i) m or f (Urdu spelling مَیں‎)
I (the first person personal singular pronoun)
examples: मैं एक आदमी हूँ।ma͠i ek ādmī hū̃.I am a man.
ma͠i ek ādmī hū̃.
I am a man.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sanskrit नहि (nahí, “surely not”), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *naǰʰí, from earlier *ná gʲʰí, from Proto-Indo-European *né + gʰí. Cognate with Assamese নাই (nai), Early Assamese নাহি (nahi), Braj नहीं (nahī̃).

text: no, not (negative response to a yes-no question)
examples: बिलकुल नहीं ― bilkul nahī̃ ― of course not
यहाँ गाजर नहीं हैंyahā̃ gājar nahī̃ ha͠ithere are no carrots here
yahā̃ gājar nahī̃ ha͠i
there are no carrots here

text: first/third-person plural present indicative of होना (honā): (we, they) are

defs.etymology:
Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀫𑀚𑁆𑀛𑁂 (majjhe), from Sanskrit मध्ये (mádhye), locative of मध्य (mádhya, “middle”), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *mádʰyas, from Proto-Indo-European *médʰyos.
The spontaneous nasalization is a common phenomenon in New Indo-Aryan. Compare Hindi साँप (sā̃p, “snake”) from Sanskrit सर्प (sarpa).
Inherited from Old Hindi एक (eka), from Sauraseni Apabhramsa एक्क (ekka), from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀏𑀓𑁆𑀓 (ekka), from Sanskrit एक (éka), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *Háykas, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *Háykas.

Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀅𑀧𑁆𑀧𑀸 (appā), from Sanskrit आत्मन् (ātmán, “soul, spirit; self”), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *HáHtmā, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *HáHtmā, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁éh₁t-mō ~ *h₁h₁t-m̥nés (“breath, spirit”), from *h₁eh₁t- (“to breathe”) +‎ *-mō. Cognate with Gujarati આપું (āpũ), Nepali आंत (ānta), Marathi आप (āp), Bengali আপনি (apni), Kamkata-viri āmu.

text: ye, you (formal, polite and grammatically plural)
examples: क्या आपको मेरी मदद की ज़रूरत है?kyā āpko merī madad kī zarūrat hai?Do you need my help?
kyā āpko merī madad kī zarūrat hai?
Do you need my help?
आपका दिन कैसा था पिताजी?āpkā din kaisā thā pitājī?How was your day, father?
āpkā din kaisā thā pitājī?
How was your day, father?
अपने आप ― apne āp ― oneself
अपना ― apnā ― one's own

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀅𑀯𑀭 (avara), from Sanskrit अपर (ápara, “other, different”).
Inherited from Old Hindi यहु (yahu), from Sauraseni Apabhramsa एहु m (ehu), एह f (eha), from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀏𑀲𑁄 m (eso), 𑀏𑀲𑀸 f (esā), from Sanskrit एषः m (eṣaḥ), एषा f (eṣā).

text: (proximal) this one; he; she; it (proximal third person singular personal pronoun)
examples: यह कौन है? ― yah kaun hai? ― Who is this [person]?
यह मकान बहुत बड़ा है। ― yah makān bahut baṛā hai. ― This house is large.

defs.etymology:
Uncertain. Several etymologies are proposed and a merger of some or all of them is likely.Inherited from Sanskrit समम् (samam, “together; similarly, as”), from सम (samá, “same”), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *samás, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *samás, from Proto-Indo-European *somHós (“same”). Compare Braj सौं (sa͠u, “to, with”).
Inherited from Sanskrit सङ्गे (saṅge), locative of सङ्ग (saṅgá, “contact; battle”). Doublet of संग (saṅg).
Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀲𑀳𑀺𑀤 (sahida), 𑀲𑀳𑀺𑀅 (sahia), from Sanskrit सहित (sahita, “with”), from स- (sa-, “with”) +‎ हित (hita, “placed”).
From Prakrit किअउं (kiauṃ) and Sanskrit कृतं (kṛtaṃ) (perfect participle neuter of कृ (kṛ, “to do”)).

Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀓𑀺𑀁 (kiṃ), 𑀓𑀺 (ki), from Sanskrit किम् (kim, “what, which”). Compare Punjabi ਕੀ (kī), Gujarati કિયું (kiyũ), Marathi की (kī), Bengali কি (ki), Assamese কি (ki). Compare Kashmiri کیاہ‎ (kyah)

text: क्या • (kyā) m or f (Urdu spelling کیا‎)
examples: आम का दाम क्या है?ām kā dām kyā hai?What is the price of mangoes?
ām kā dām kyā hai?
What is the price of mangoes?
क्या हुआ? ― kyā huā? ― What happened?
क्या गाता है यह!kyā gātā hai yah!Such [finely] he sings!
kyā gātā hai yah!
Such [finely] he sings!
क्या जाने ― kyā jāne ― who knows

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Persian که‎ (ke).

examples: मुझे मालूम नहीं था कि तुम्हें मराठी आती है।mujhe mālūm nahī̃ thā ki tumhẽ marāṭhī ātī hai.I didn't know that you speak Marathi
mujhe mālūm nahī̃ thā ki tumhẽ marāṭhī ātī hai.
I didn't know that you speak Marathi

defs.etymology: See क्या (kyā, “what”).
Inherited from Sauraseni Apabhramsa तुम्हि, from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀢𑀼𑀫𑁆𑀳𑁂 (tumhe), from Sanskrit युष्मान् (yuṣmān, “you”, acc. pl.) adopting the initial sounds of त्वम् (tvám, “you”, nom. sg.).

text: you, ye (mid-level formality and grammatically plural)

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Sanskrit कर (kara).

examples: Synonyms: हस्त , हाथ
वस्तु और सेवा कर ― vastu aur sevā kar ― Goods and services tax

defs.etymology: Inflection of करना (karnā, “to do”).

Inherited from Old Hindi काहू (kāhū), काहु (kāhu), from Sauraseni Prakrit [Term?], from Sanskrit कक्षे (kákṣe, “in the armpit”), locative singular of कक्ष (kákṣa, “armpit”), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *káṭṣas, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *káćšas, from Proto-Indo-European *kóḱsos (“joint”). Compare Deccani کو‎ (kū), Braj कौ (kau), Assamese -ক (-k).
The semantic development of the terms was in the armpit > at the side > towards > to. Deccani (and other Southern dialects of Hindustani) had a parallel development which also includes a locative sense.

Inherited from Old Hindi हम (hama), हंम (haṃma), from Sauraseni Apabhramsa अम्हे (amhe), from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀅𑀫𑁆𑀳𑁂 (amhe), from Ashokan Prakrit [Term?], from Sanskrit अस्मे (asme) (locative of वयम् (vayam, “we”)), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *asmáy, from Proto-Indo-European *n̥smé. Compare Punjabi ਅਸੀਂ (asī̃), Assamese আমি (ami),  Bengali আমি (ami), Marathi आम्ही (āmhī), Konkani आमि (āmi).

text: हम • (ham) m or f (Urdu spelling ہم‎)
we: first-person plural personal pronoun, plural of मैं (ma͠i)
(Varanasi, Awadh, colloquial in Standard Hindi) I: first-person personal singular personal pronoun
examples: हम बहुत पहले से एक-दूसरे को जानते हैं।ham bahut pahle se ek-dūsre ko jānte ha͠i.We've known each other for a long time.
ham bahut pahle se ek-dūsre ko jānte ha͠i.
We've known each other for a long time.
Synonym: मैं

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Persian هم‎ (ham), from Middle Persian hm (ham), from Old Persian 𐏃𐎶 (hama), from Proto-Iranian *hamHáh, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *samHás, from Proto-Indo-European *somHós. Doublet of सम (sam), a Sanskrit borrowing.
From Sanskrit स्थित (sthita).

text: masculine singular imperfect indicative of होना (honā)

defs.etymology:
Uncertain.
Most likely from Old Hindi उहु (uhu), उहुं (uhuṃ), from Sauraseni Apabhramsa ओहु (ohu), from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀅𑀳𑁄 (aho), from Sanskrit असौ (asáu, “that”). The inflected forms are formed by analogy with its proximal counterpart यह (yah).
For Old Hindi वो (vo), Chatterji suggested a derivation from Sauraseni Apabhramsa ओ (o), from Sanskrit *अव (ava), attested in अवोष् (avoṣ), अवोर् (avor, “of you both”, gen. du.), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *avá. He suggested the term not being preserved in literature but continuing to be spoken. Compare Avestan 𐬀𐬬𐬀‎ (ava).
Note that the second etymology explains plural वे (ve) as well, while the first does not. See there for more.

text: (distal) he, she, it; that one (distal third person singular personal pronoun)
examples: वह मकान बड़ा है। ― vah makān baṛā hai. ― That house is large.
वह छोटा है। ― vah choṭā hai. ― He is small.
वह छोटी है। ― vah choṭī hai. ― She is small.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀧𑀭𑀺 (pari), 𑀉𑀧𑁆𑀧𑀭𑀺 (uppari), from Sanskrit उपरि (upari, “above”).
Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀧𑀭𑀁 (paraṃ), from Sanskrit परम् (param, “after, but”), oblique of पर (para, “distant, further”).

examples: मैंने दूध पिया, पर मैंने नाश्ता नहीं किया।mainne dūdh piyā, par mainne nāśtā nahī̃ kiyā.I drank milk, however I did not have breakfast.
mainne dūdh piyā, par mainne nāśtā nahī̃ kiyā.
I drank milk, however I did not have breakfast.
Synonyms: see Thesaurus:मगर

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Persian پر‎ (par).

examples: Synonym: पंख

defs.etymology: Learned borrowing from Sanskrit पर (para).

examples: Synonym: दूर

text: first-person singular present indicative/subjunctive of होना (honā)

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀯𑀺 (vi), 𑀧𑀺 (pi), 𑀅𑀯𑀺 (avi), from Sanskrit अपि (api).

examples: तुम भी जाओगी? ― tum bhī jāogī? ― Will you too go?
और वो भी दो ― aur vo bhī do ― And, also give me that.

text: Often reduced to [‿ɾä] in speech, as it is normally said after verb forms. For example, मैं कर रहा हूँ। ― [mɛ̃ kəɾ‿ɾä ɦũ] ― I am doing (it).
Optionally transformed to [lːä] in speech, when preceded by words that end in /l/. For example, क्या चल रहा है? ― [kjäː t͡ʃəlːä ɦɛː] ― What's going on?.

defs.etymology: From a derivative of Sanskrit कृ (kṛ, “to do”), likely कृत (kṛta, “done”) or कार्य (kārya, “to be done”). Dasa also suggests -क (-ka, diminutive suffix). Compare Punjabi ਦਾ (dā).

From, undergoing metathesis, Old Hindi कछु (kachu), from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀓𑀺𑀁𑀘𑀺 (kiṃci), from Sanskrit किंचिद् (kiṃcid), neuter singular of कश्चिद् (kaścid, “someone”) (whence कोई (koī, “anyone”)).
The -ch- reflects -śc- in Sanskrit कश्चिद् (kaścid).

examples: वह कल रात उससे कुछ कह रही थी।vah kal rāt usse kuch kah rahī thī.She was saying something to her last night.
vah kal rāt usse kuch kah rahī thī.
She was saying something to her last night.
उसको कुछ हिंदी आती है। ― usko kuch hindī ātī hai. ― He knows some Hindi.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit, probably from Sanskrit ततस् (tatas, “from there”).

text: then (in that case; at that time)
examples: अगर वह जाएगा तो मैं भी जाऊँगा।agar vah jāegā to ma͠i bhī jāūṅgā.If he goes, [then] I will go too.
agar vah jāegā to ma͠i bhī jāūṅgā.
If he goes, [then] I will go too.
तो हम क्या करें? ― to ham kyā karẽ? ― So what do we do?
सच तो यह है कि आज घर पे ही रहा।sac to yah hai ki āj ghar pe hī rahā.The truth is, actually, that I stayed at home today.
sac to yah hai ki āj ghar pe hī rahā.
The truth is, actually, that I stayed at home today.
बोलो तो! ― bolo to! ― Say [something] at least!
तो भी ― to bhī ― even then

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sanskrit गया (gayā).
Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀕𑀅 (gaa) +  Middle Indo-Aryan -𑀓- (-ka-), from Sanskrit गत (gatá, “gone”).

examples: वह घर गया। ― vah ghar gayā. ― He went home.

defs.etymology: Related to Punjabi ਇਸ (is, es). Inherited from Sanskrit इदम् (idám) or  Sanskrit एषः (eṣaḥ).

text: this - oblique case only, see below for direct.
him - oblique case only, near reference. (If respect is conveyed, इन (in) is used)
her - oblique case only, near reference. (If respect is conveyed, इन (in) is used)
examples: इस मकान में छह कमरे हैis makān mẽ chah kamre haiIn this house there are six rooms
is makān mẽ chah kamre hai
In this house there are six rooms
इसको पैसे दे दोisko paise de doGive money to him
isko paise de do
Give money to him
इसको पैसे दे दो ― isko paise de do ― Give money to her
इस लो ― is lo ― Take it

defs.etymology: Inherited from Ashokan Prakrit *𑀞𑀻𑀓𑁆𑀓 (*ṭhīkka). Related to ठिकाना (ṭhikānā). Cognate with Punjabi ਠੀਕ (ṭhīk) / ٹھِیک‎ (ṭhīk), Gujarati ઠીક (ṭhīk), Sindhi ٺيِڪُ‎ / ठीकु, Marathi ठीक (ṭhīk), Oriya ଠିକ (ṭhikô), Bengali ঠিক (ṭhik).

text: immediate; very close, direct, or adjacent
examples: अपनी ग़लतियाँ झट से ठीक करना चाहिए।apnī ġaltiyā̃ jhaṭ se ṭhīk karnā cāhie.You should quickly correct your mistakes.
apnī ġaltiyā̃ jhaṭ se ṭhīk karnā cāhie.
You should quickly correct your mistakes.
हाँ, मैं ठीक हूँ। ― hā̃, ma͠i ṭhīk hū̃. ― Yes, I'm fine.

defs.etymology: From Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀓𑀺𑀤𑀕 (kidaga), from Ashokan Prakrit *𑀓𑀺𑀢 (*kita) +  Middle Indo-Aryan -𑀓- (-ka-), from Sanskrit कृत (kṛtá), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *kr̥tás, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *kr̥tás, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷr̥-tó-s (“done”), from *kʷer- (“to do, make”). Cognate with Avestan 𐬐𐬆𐬭𐬆𐬙𐬀‎‎ (kərəta‎), Kamkata-viri křa. Doublet of कृत (kŕt).
Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀲𑀢𑁆𑀣 (sattha), from Sanskrit सार्थ (sā́rtha). Doublet of सार्थ (sārth).

examples: साथ चलते हैं। ― sāth calte ha͠i. ― Let's walk together.
अपने भाई का साथ कभी  न छोड़ो।apne bhāī kā sāth kabhī  na choṛo.Never leave your brother's side.
apne bhāī kā sāth kabhī  na choṛo.
Never leave your brother's side.

text: (polite) dative of वह (vah); to him, her, it
examples: उसे ज़्यादा डांटो नहीं। ― use zyādā ḍā̃ṭo nahī̃. ― Don't scold him so much.
Synonym: उसको

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀳𑀸𑀫𑁆𑀫 (hāmma), from Sanskrit आम् (ām).

examples: हाँ बोलना ― hā̃ bolnā ― to say yes

defs.etymology: Inherited from Old Hindi वे (ve), वै (vai), from Sauraseni Apabhramsa ओइ (oi), perhaps ultimately from Sanskrit *अव (ava), attested in अवोष् (avoṣ), अवोर् (avor, “of you both”, gen. du.), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *avá. Compare Avestan 𐬀𐬬𐬀‎ (ava).

text: वे • (ve) m pl or f pl (Urdu spelling وہ‎) (demonstrative)
examples: वे अच्छे लोग हैं। ― ve acche log ha͠i. ― They are good people.
उन मकानों में छह कमरे हैं।un makānõ mẽ chah kamre ha͠i.In those houses there are six rooms.
un makānõ mẽ chah kamre ha͠i.
In those houses there are six rooms.

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Classical Persian لیکن‎ (lekin), from Arabic لٰكِنْ‎ (lākin).

examples: Synonyms: पर , परंतु , किंतु , मगर

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀇𑀥 (idha), 𑀇𑀳 (iha), from Sanskrit इह (ihá), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *Hidʰá, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *Hidʰá, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁i-dʰe- (“here”).

Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit, from Sanskrit कश्चिद् (káścid). Likely also influenced by Sanskrit कोऽपि (kó’pi). Cognate to Awadhi कोई (koī), Braj कोऊ (koū), Punjabi ਕੋਈ (koī), Gujarati કોઈ (koī), Marathi कुणी (kuṇī), Bengali কেউ (keu), Bhojpuri केऊ (keū), Assamese কেও (keü).

text: कोई • (koī) m or f (Urdu spelling کوئی‎)
examples: क्या यहाँ कोई है? ― kyā yahā̃ koī hai? ― Is anyone here?

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Arabic طَرْح‎ (ṭarḥ).

text: तरह • (tarah or tarha) f (Urdu spelling طرح‎)
examples: Synonym: प्रकार
यह किस तरह से बना है? ― yah kis tarah se banā hai? ― By what method is this made?
Synonyms: ढंग , तरीक़ा
Synonym: हाल

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sanskrit अ (a) + एवम् एव (evam eva). Compare जब (jab), तब (tab), and कब (kab).

examples: अब क्या करोगे? ― ab kyā karoge? ― What will you do now?
जायज़ है कि घोड़े नहीं उड़ सकते, अब वो कोई पंछी हैं क्या?jāyaz hai ki ghoṛe nahī̃ uṛ sakte, ab vo koī pañchī ha͠i kyā?It's obvious that horses can't fly, after all they are not birds.
jāyaz hai ki ghoṛe nahī̃ uṛ sakte, ab vo koī pañchī ha͠i kyā?
It's obvious that horses can't fly, after all they are not birds.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀧𑀢𑁆𑀢 (patta), from Sanskrit पत्त्र (páttra, “leaf, paper, letter, document”). Doublet of पत्ता (pattā).

examples: पता करना ― patā karnā ― to find out
पता लगना ― patā lagnā ― to come to know
Synonyms: मालूम , ज्ञात

text: second/third-person singular masculine future indicative of होना (honā)

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀩𑀳𑀼𑀢𑁆𑀢 (bahutta), from Sanskrit बहुत्व (bahutva, “abundance”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰenǵʰ- (“thick”). Compare Assamese বহুত (bohut), Gujarati બહુ (bahu).

examples: बहुत-सारा ― bahut-sārā ― very many, too much
मैं बहुत अच्छा हूँ। ma͠i bahut acchā hū̃.I'm very well
ma͠i bahut acchā hū̃.
I'm very well
मैं बहुत अच्छी हूँ। ma͠i bahut acchī hū̃.I'm very well
ma͠i bahut acchī hū̃.
I'm very well

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sanskrit वार्त्ता (vārttā).

examples: वह अपनी बात का धनी है।vah apnī bāt kā dhanī hai.He is true to his word.
vah apnī bāt kā dhanī hai.
He is true to his word.
मेरी उसने रोचक बात हुई।merī usne rocak bāt huī.I had an interesting talk with him.
merī usne rocak bāt huī.
I had an interesting talk with him.
बात यहीं पर समाप्त नहीं होता।bāt yahī̃ par samāpt nahī̃ hotā.The matter does not end here.
bāt yahī̃ par samāpt nahī̃ hotā.
The matter does not end here.
क्या बात है? ― kyā bāt hai? ― What is the matter?
महत्त्वपूर्ण बात यह है।mahattvapūrṇ bāt yah hai.The important thing is this.
mahattvapūrṇ bāt yah hai.
The important thing is this.
आपकी बात नहीं समझा।āpkī bāt nahī̃ samjhā.I don't see your point.
āpkī bāt nahī̃ samjhā.
I don't see your point.

defs.etymology: Borrowed from English baht, from Thai บาท (bàat), from Pali pāda (quarter of a larger valued coin) or Sanskrit पाद (quarter).

text: baht (official currency of Thailand, equal to 100 satang)

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Persian سکته‎ (sakte), from Arabic سَكْتَة‎ (sakta).

Inherited from Sanskrit हि (hi, emphatic particle) likely with some other particle such as एव (eva, “indeed”) or वै (vai, “indeed”). Compare the functionally equivalent Gujarati જ (ja), Marathi -च (-ċ) (whence Bombay Hindi -ईच (-īc)).
Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀤𑀻𑀯 (dīva), from Sanskrit दीप (dīpa). Doublet of दीप (dīp). Cognate to Punjabi ਦੀਵਾ (dīvā), Nepali दियो (diyo), Gujarati દીવો (dīvo), Marathi दिवा (divā).

examples: Synonyms: दीप , दीपक , चिराग़

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀓𑀭𑁂𑀤𑀺 (karedi), from Sanskrit करोति (karóti), an alternation Vedic Sanskrit कृणोति (kṛṇóti). Cognate with Punjabi ਕਰਨਾ (karnā), Nepali गर्नु (garnu), Gujarati કરવું (karvũ), Marathi करणे (karṇe), Bengali করা (kôra), Assamese কৰ (kor), and Persian کردن‎.

text: (transitive) to do (to perform or execute, to commit)
(transitive) to cause to become, to render
(transitive) an element of a compound verb: makes most (especially borrowed) adjectives and nouns into verbs
examples: कर देना ― kar denā ― to accomplish, complete
कर लेना ― kar lenā ― to do , to decide and do
कर सकना ― kar saknā ― to be able to do
कर पाना ― kar pānā ― to have succeeded in doing
कर दिखाना ― kar dikhānā ― to show that it can be done, prove
फ़र्ज़ करना ― farz karnā ― to perform one's duty
तू क्या कर रहा है?tū kyā kar rahā hai?What are you doing?
tū kyā kar rahā hai?
What are you doing?
कर्तव्य कर्म करना चाहिए। ― kartavya karm karnā cāhie. ― One must do the necessary work.
हम बनारस को तीर्थयात्रा करेंगे।ham banāras ko tīrthayātrā kareṅge.We will make a pilgrimage to Varanasi.
ham banāras ko tīrthayātrā kareṅge.
We will make a pilgrimage to Varanasi.
उसकी बहन क्या करती है? ― uskī bahan kyā kartī hai? ― What work does his sister do?
Synonym: काम करना
गड़बड़ी करना ― gaṛabṛī karnā ― to make a mess
मैं हमेशा आपकी सहायता करूँगा।ma͠i hameśā āpkī sahāytā karūṅgā.I will always render help to you.
ma͠i hameśā āpkī sahāytā karūṅgā.
I will always render help to you.
फ्रेंच करना ― phreñc karnā ― to render  into French
टैक्सी करना ― ṭaiksī karnā ― to hire a taxi
मैं जंप करते समय गिर पड़ा।ma͠i jamp karte samay gir paṛā.I fell while jumping.
ma͠i jamp karte samay gir paṛā.
I fell while jumping.
साफ़ करना ― sāf karnā ― to clean
ग़लती करनाġaltī karnāto make a mistake; do incorrectly
ġaltī karnā
to make a mistake; do incorrectly
डांस करना ― ḍāns karnā ― to dance
See Category:Hindi compound verbs with base verb करना for more.
मैं रोज़ परिवार के साथ खाया करता था।ma͠i roz parivār ke sāth khāyā kartā thā.I used to eat with my family every day.
ma͠i roz parivār ke sāth khāyā kartā thā.
I used to eat with my family every day.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀲𑀩𑁆𑀩 (sabba), 𑀲𑀯𑁆𑀯 (savva), from Ashokan Prakrit 𑀲𑀯𑁆𑀯 (savva), 𑀲𑀭𑁆𑀯 (sarva), from Sanskrit सर्व (sárva), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *sárwas, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *sárwas, from Proto-Indo-European *solh₂-wó-s, from *solh₂- (“whole”). Doublet of हर (har) and सर्व (sarv). Cognate with Kamkata-viri suv, Persian هر‎ (har).

examples: सबको पता है मैं कौन हूँ। ― sabko patā hai ma͠i kaun hū̃. ― Everybody knows who I am.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀓𑀳𑀸 (kahā), from Sanskrit कथा (kathā).

examples: मेरा कहा सही साबित होने वाला है।merā kahā sahī sābit hone vālā hai.My claim is about to be proven.
merā kahā sahī sābit hone vālā hai.
My claim is about to be proven.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀚𑁄 (jo), from Sanskrit यः (yáḥ), from Proto-Indo-Aryan *Hyás, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *Hyás, from Proto-Indo-European *Hyós. Compare इस (is).

text: जो • (jo) m or f (Urdu spelling جو‎)
examples: जिसको सेब चाहिये क्या वह अपना हाथ उठा सकता है?jisko seb cāhiye kyā vah apnā hāth uṭhā saktā hai?Whoever wants an apple can they raise their hand?
jisko seb cāhiye kyā vah apnā hāth uṭhā saktā hai?
Whoever wants an apple can they raise their hand?
जो भी हो सो हो। ― jo bhī ho so ho. ― Whatever happens will happen.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀚𑀑 (jao), from Sanskrit यतः (yátaḥ), from the pronominal base य (yá).

examples: जो मैंने ऐसा किया ... ― jo mainne aisā kiyā ... ― If I had done that ...
Synonyms: अगर , यदि

text: there (only in the sense of an abstract noun of place. Hindi does not have a word equivalent to the English usage for "there is...".)

defs.etymology: From अब (ab, “now”). Cognate with Punjabi ਜਦੋਂ (jadõ) / جدوں‎ (jadõ).

examples: जब मैं छोटा था, मैं ख़ूब तेज़ होता था।jab ma͠i choṭā thā, ma͠i xūb tez hotā thā.When I was little, I used to be very mischievous.
jab ma͠i choṭā thā, ma͠i xūb tez hotā thā.
When I was little, I used to be very mischievous.

text: (polite) dative of यह (yah); to him, her, it
examples: Synonym: इसको

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀅𑀘𑁆𑀙 (accha), from Sanskrit अच्छ (accha). Displaced आछा (āchā), from the same source.

examples: इस साल क्या आप अच्छे थे? ― is sāl kyā āp acche the? ― Were you good this year?
अच्छा बच्चा ― acchā baccā ― good boy
अच्छा दिन ― acchā din ― good day
Synonym: उत्तम
Antonyms: बुरा , ख़राब
यह खाना बहुत ही अच्छा है!yah khānā bahut hī acchā hai!This food is quite delicious!
yah khānā bahut hī acchā hai!
This food is quite delicious!
अच्छी मिठाई ― acchī miṭhāī ― tasty sweets
Synonym: स्वादिष्ट
क्या तुमने अच्छा किया? ― kyā tumne acchā kiyā? ― Did you do well?

text: oh! (often with stress on the final syllable)
examples: अच्छा! तो मैं सही था! ― acchā! to ma͠i sahī thā! ― Oh! So I was correct!

text: third-person plural present imperative of चाहना (cāhnā): should, ought to

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀩𑀸𑀳𑀺𑀭 (bāhira), from Sanskrit बहिर् (bahir), a compounding form of बहिस् (bahis). Compare Marathi बाहेर (bāher), Assamese বাহিৰ (bahir).

examples: कहीं बाहर चलते हैं खाने के लिए।kahī̃ bāhar calte ha͠i khāne ke lie.Let's go out for food.
kahī̃ bāhar calte ha͠i khāne ke lie.
Let's go out for food.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Apabhramsa किंव, ultimately from Sanskrit किम् (kim, “what”). Cognate with Assamese কিয় (kio).

examples: तूने इस तरह का घर क्यों बनाया?tūne is tarah kā ghar kyõ banāyā?Why did you make this kind of house?
tūne is tarah kā ghar kyõ banāyā?
Why did you make this kind of house?
क्यों नहीं? ― kyõ nahī̃? ― Why not?

text: masculine plural imperfect indicative of होना (honā)

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sanskrit द्व (dvá), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *dwáH, from Proto-Indo-European *dwóh₁.

text: दो • (do) (native script symbol २, Urdu spelling دو‎) (cardinal)

examples: मुझे पैसे दो ― mujhe paise do ― Give me the money!

defs.etymology: From किस (kis) +‎ ही (hī).

text: oblique of कोई (koī): some, a certain, a given
examples: किसी संख्या का एक-पाँचवाँ भाग बीस है, तो उस संख्या का चार-पाँचवाँ भाग कितना होगा?kisī saṅkhyā kā ek-pā̃cvā̃ bhāg bīs hai, to us saṅkhyā kā cār-pā̃cvā̃ bhāg kitnā hogā?One-fifth of a given number is twenty, so how much will four-fifths of that number be?
kisī saṅkhyā kā ek-pā̃cvā̃ bhāg bīs hai, to us saṅkhyā kā cār-pā̃cvā̃ bhāg kitnā hogā?
One-fifth of a given number is twenty, so how much will four-fifths of that number be?

defs.etymology: Related to फिरना (phirnā, “to roam”). Compare Punjabi ਫਿਰ (phir), Nepali फेरि (pheri), Gujarati ફરી (pharī).

examples: मुझे मेरी नौकरी से निकाल दिया गया था। फिर मैं काम ढूँढने  दिल्ली आ गया।mujhe merī naukrī se nikāl diyā gayā thā. phir ma͠i kām ḍhūṇḍhne  dillī ā gayā.I was fired from my job. Then, I came to Delhi to find work.
mujhe merī naukrī se nikāl diyā gayā thā. phir ma͠i kām ḍhūṇḍhne  dillī ā gayā.
I was fired from my job. Then, I came to Delhi to find work.
फिर क्या ― phir kyā ― then what
फिर भी ― phir bhī ― even then
Synonym: तो
हम ज़रूर फिर मिलेंगे। ― ham zarūr phir mileṅge. ― We will surely meet again.
फिर से ― phir se ― again
Synonym: दुबारा

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀓𑀫𑁆𑀫 (kamma), from Sanskrit कर्मन् (kárman). Doublet of कर्म (karm). Cognate with Punjabi ਕੱਮ (kamma), Assamese কাম (kam).

examples: मैं कारख़ाने में काम करता हूँ।ma͠i kārxāne mẽ kām kartā hū̃.I work at a factory.
ma͠i kārxāne mẽ kām kartā hū̃.
I work at a factory.
Synonym: क्रिया
आजकल मैं काम की तलाश कर रहा हूँ।ājkal ma͠i kām kī talāś kar rahā hū̃.These days I am looking for a job.
ājkal ma͠i kām kī talāś kar rahā hū̃.
These days I am looking for a job.
Synonyms: नौकरी , रोज़गार
यह बक्सा मेज़ का काम देगा।yah baksā mez kā kām degā.This box will serve the function of a table.
yah baksā mez kā kām degā.
This box will serve the function of a table.

defs.etymology: Learned borrowing from Sanskrit काम (kāma), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *kā́ma.

examples: Synonym: कामदेव

defs.etymology: From Sanskrit अगरु (agaru). Ultimately from Tamil அகில் (akil, “eagle-wood”).
Borrowed from Persian اگر‎ (agar), from Middle Persian 𐭧𐭲‎ (ḥt /agar/).

examples: अगर मैंने यह किया होता तो ...agar mainne yah kiyā hotā to ...If I had done this, then ...
agar mainne yah kiyā hotā to ...
If I had done this, then ...
Synonym: यदि

text: this; he, she, it (near reference, direct case, colloquial for यह)
examples: ये मकान बड़े हैं ― ye makān baṛe ha͠i ― These houses are large
ये छोटे हैं ― ye choṭe ha͠i ― He is small
ये छोटी हैं ― ye choṭī ha͠i ― She is small
ये कौन हैं? ― ye kaun ha͠i? ― Who are they?

defs.etymology: From Sanskrit कीदृश् (kīdṛś).

examples: यह कैसे हुआ? ― yah kaise huā? ― How did this happen?

defs.etymology: From the oblique masculine form of पहला (pahlā, “first”).
Borrowed from Persian بس‎ (bas).

examples: मैं बस यह कहना चाहता था कि ...ma͠i bas yah kahnā cāhtā thā ki ...I only wanted to say that ...
ma͠i bas yah kahnā cāhtā thā ki ...
I only wanted to say that ...
Synonyms: केवल , सिर्फ़
बस! तमाशा बंद करो! ― bas! tamāśā band karo! ― Enough! Stop this nonsense!
बस, इतना ठीक है ― bas, itnā ṭhīk hai ― Enough, this much is fine.

defs.etymology: Borrowed from English bus.

examples: बस सेवा ― bas sevā ― bus service

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀯𑀲 (vasa), from Sanskrit वश (vaśa), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *wášas.

examples: यह काम तेरे बस का नहीं है।yah kām tere bas kā nahī̃ hai.This work is beyond your ability.
yah kām tere bas kā nahī̃ hai.
This work is beyond your ability.
बस में ― bas mẽ ― in one's abilities

defs.etymology: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

text: second/third-person singular masculine future indicative of जाना (jānā)

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Persian آدمی‎ (âdami), from Arabic آدَمِيّ‎ (ʾādamiyy, “human”), from آدَم‎ (ʾādam, “Adam”), from Proto-Semitic *ʾadm-.

examples: आदमी बहुत स्वार्थी प्राणी है।ādmī bahut svārthī prāṇī hai.Man is a selfish being.
ādmī bahut svārthī prāṇī hai.
Man is a selfish being.
Synonyms: इंसान ,  मनुष्य
Antonyms: जानवर , पशु
क्या वह आदमी है या औरत? ― kyā vah ādmī hai yā aurat? ― Is he a man or a woman?
Synonyms: पुरुष , नर , मर्द
Antonyms: औरत , स्त्री , नारी , महिला

defs.etymology: कब (kab) +‎ ही (hī).

examples: कभी कभी ― kabhī kabhī ― sometimes
कभी नहीं ― kabhī nahī̃ ― never
Synonyms: कदापि , हरगिज़

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Sanskrit समय (samayá).

examples: Synonym: वक़्त
इसमें कितना समय लगता है? ― ismẽ kitnā samay lagtā hai? ― How much time does this take?
घर जाने का समय लगभग हो गया है।ghar jāne kā samay lagbhag ho gayā hai.It is about time to go home.
ghar jāne kā samay lagbhag ho gayā hai.
It is about time to go home.
मिलने का समय कब है? ― milne kā samay kab hai? ― When are visiting hours?

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Persian واپس‎ (vâpas).

examples: वापस आना ― vāpas ānā ― to come back
वापस देना ― vāpas denā ― to return
पैसे वापस देना ― paise vāpas denā ― to return money
Synonym: हमको

text: The first three transcriptions are very common, but the fourth is the true phonetic value.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Sauraseni Prakrit *𑀢𑀯𑀓𑁆𑀓 (*tavakka), *𑀢𑀸𑀯𑀓𑁆𑀓 (*tāvakka), from Sanskrit तावत्क (tā́vatka, “bought for so much”). Cognate with Punjabi ਤੱਕ (takka) / تّک‎ (takk).

From Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀫𑀏 (mae) +‎ रा (rā, genitive affix). The first element is from Sanskrit मे (me), variant dative of अहम् (aham). For the second element, compare का (kā, genitive affix).
Cognate with Persian مرا‎ (marâ).
